summary: This document is a chain of email correspondence from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY) requesting and approving travel for the investigative team working on the Epstein case (United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618). The emails detail multiple trips planned between March 2019 and February 2020 to conduct victim interviews in Los Angeles, West Palm Beach, Fort Lauderdale, and near Stockholm, Sweden.

persons.name: Edward Tyrrell
persons.context: Recipient and approver of travel requests for the SDNY Epstein investigation team. He sends approval responses.

persons.name: Alex
persons.context: Primary author of the travel approval requests for the Epstein investigation team. Coordinates travel for victim interviews.

persons.name: Darlene Alleyne
persons.context: Copied on multiple travel request emails, indicating involvement in the administrative or logistical aspects of the investigation.

persons.name: Michele Duncan
persons.context: Copied on several travel request emails, indicating involvement in the investigation's administrative support.

persons.name: Alison
persons.context: Member of the Epstein investigation team who travels to conduct victim interviews in West Palm Beach and Los Angeles.

persons.name: Maurene
persons.context: Member of the Epstein investigation team who travels to conduct victim interviews in West Palm Beach and Los Angeles.

connections.description: Alex submits travel requests to Edward Tyrrell for approval, indicating a supervisor-subordinate or requester-approver relationship within the U.S. Attorney's Office.
They are part of the same investigation team, with Alex coordinating travel for Alison to conduct interviews.
They are part of the same investigation team, with Alex coordinating travel for Maurene to conduct interviews.
Both are investigators on the Epstein case who travel together or in various combinations to conduct victim interviews.
Both are copied on internal administrative emails regarding investigation travel, indicating they work in the same office or unit.

events.title: Planned Florida Interviews
events.description: Travel requested for meetings and interviews in West Palm Beach and/or Fort Lauderdale, Florida, for the Epstein investigation.

events.title: West Palm Beach Interviews
events.description: Travel requested for Alison and Alex to conduct meetings and interviews in West Palm Beach, Florida.

events.title: West Palm Beach Victim Interviews
events.description: Travel requested for victim interviews in West Palm Beach, Florida. Team composition to be either Alex and Alison or Alison and Maurene.

events.title: Los Angeles Victim Interview
events.description: Travel requested for a victim interview in Los Angeles. Team to include some combination of Alex, Alison, and/or Maurene.

events.title: West Palm Beach Interview
events.description: Travel requested for Alex and Maurene to conduct an interview in West Palm Beach on November 4.

events.title: Los Angeles Interview
events.description: Travel requested for an interview in Los Angeles.

events.title: Los Angeles Interviews
events.description: Travel requested for an interview or interviews in Los Angeles.

events.title: International Interview in Sweden
events.description: Travel requested for an interview near Stockholm, Sweden, noted as having an 'added international element'.

events.title: Los Angeles Interview Series
events.description: Travel requested for three interviews in Los Angeles over three days (Feb 26-28).

keyFacts: The document reveals ongoing, active investigation into the Epstein case (United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618) by the SDNY from at least March 2019 through February 2020, well after Epstein's arrest and death.
The investigation involved extensive travel to conduct victim interviews, with trips to Los Angeles, West Palm Beach, Fort Lauderdale, and an international trip to Sweden in January 2020.
The investigative team included AUSA Alex and investigators Alison and Maurene, with travel approvals overseen by Edward Tyrrell.
The case is formally described as 'an investigation relating to enticement of minors for sexual activity'.
The emails show a pattern of requesting hotel conference rooms for conducting interviews during these trips.
